response.answer_text: We are promised in the Bible we will live forever on the earth. John 3:16 says ““for God so loved the world he gave his only begotten so so those who believeth in him may not die but have everlasting life. So God, through his son grants us everlasting life if we exercise faith in Jesus. In Psalms 37:9–11–29 says man will live forever on the earth in peace. In Acts 24:15 God promises a resurrection of our dead loved ones back to earth in the last day. In Revelation 21:4 says there’ll be no more pain or death. God’s original purpose was for man to live forever in the garden of eden. God’s purpose hasn’t changed. In Romans 5:21 says ““so that just as sin ruled as king with death, so also underserved kindness might rule as king through righteousness, heading to everlasting life through Jesus Christ our Lord.” So we are guaranteed everlasting life through the end of this system or at our resurrection. When Jesus resurrected Lazarus from the dead, it was to earth. That was a foregleam of the future.

Lets look it this way. The existence of any object has a life cycle. The creation, existence and destruction. So, for every creation leads to existence, which ends up in destruction. If your focus remains on creating beautiful memories in existence phase, there is nothing to worry about creation or destruction. Its our responsibility to live the fullest in our existence phase.

Death exists in order to free up resources for the new and potentially more fit, fit for the environment that a given species operates in. As a specie’s environment changes, the species changes to allow it to survive, the species that is, not the individuals. I can imagine a future where science has figured out how to allow individual humans to be able to enjoy the adaptability that the species enjoys. That would make death, for humans, unnecessary.
Not at all. Death is the only sure thing in life!
